summary: expression levels of 11 potential reference genes in avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) were determined by real-time PCR. the genes RPL30 (ribosomal protein L30) and SDHA (succinate dehydrogenase complex, subunit A) were the most stably expressed genes in the ALV-J infected CEF. the selection of reference genes should ideally be determined for each specific cell type and virus. chicken embryonic fibroblasts (CEF) are frequently used for propagation of ALV-J. those fibroblasts have also been used as model cells for the study of host-virus interaction. if RPL4 is excluded, V2/3 = 0.129 is a bit higher than V3/4, but still lower than cut-off value of 0.15. the optimal number of reference genes for normalization was determined by the geNorm software. Yin et al. compared the expression of 10 candidate reference genes in cell lines infected with 6 human viruses. found that ACTB is unsuitable as reference gene, whereas TATA-Box binding protein (TBP) and peptidyl-prolyl-isomerase A were stable genes for use as reference genes in expression studies. the protocol was approved by the Ethical Committee for animal experiments of Southwest University for Nationalities. the cells were seeded (approximately 5 106cells/well) in 24-well culture plates. after 1 h incubation, the cells were washed and further incubated in media with 2% FBS. housekeeping genes, previously used as references for the evaluation of expression stability in CEF infected with avian influenza virus, were also used as candidate reference genes in the present study.
